facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 22 of 1954 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 22 of 1954. 1446 Appeal under Article

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 27th October 1953 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Reference No. 121 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 134 1   c  of the Constitution from the Judgment and Order dated the 27th October 1953 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Reference No. 121 of 1953.

facts.text: Three persons including the appellant were parcel porters at Manikpur railway station in Banda district, Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Three persons including the appellant were, at the material time, parcel porters at the railway station Manikpur in the district Banda of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: On the night of 18th June 1952, three persons including appellant found committing theft of packets of biscuits by breaking open a railway parcel.

anchor.surface_text: On the night of the 18th June, 1952, they were found by two watchmen of the Watch and Ward staff attached to the railway station, companymitting theft of certain packets of biscuits by breaking open a railway parcel

facts.text: Found by two watchmen of Watch and Ward staff at railway station.

anchor.surface_text: On the night of the 18th June, 1952, they were found by two watchmen of the Watch and Ward staff attached to the railway station,

facts.text: First information lodged by Ram Prasad, Head Watchman, before Sub-Inspector, Railway Police.

anchor.surface_text: companytaining those packets, which as parcel porters, they had occasion to handle. First information of the same was lodged, before the Sub-Inspector, Railway Police, by one Ram Prasad, Head Watchman.

facts.text: Railway Police filed charge-sheet under section 379 IPC on 20th June 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Railway Police filed the charge-sheet under section 379 of the Indian Penal Code on the 20th June, 1952.

facts.text: Railway Magistrate, Manikpur took cognizance of the case.

anchor.surface_text: The case was taken companynizance of by the Railway Magistrate, Manikpur.

facts.text: All three accused pleaded guilty.

anchor.surface_text: All the three accused pleaded guilty.

facts.text: Convicted by Magistrate on 15th July 1952 and sentenced to fine of Rs. 25 each.

anchor.surface_text: They were companyvicted by the Magistrate on the 15th July, 1952, and sentenced to a fine of Rs. 25 each.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision to Sessions Judge of Banda against conviction.

anchor.surface_text: Against this companyviction the present appellant filed a revision to the Sessions Judge of Banda.

facts.text: Sessions Judge accepted contention that case should be tried by Panchayati Adalat, Railway Magistrate had no jurisdiction, referred to High Court for quashing conviction.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary at this stage to mention that under the U. P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947, the Panchayati Adalats in U. P. have criminal jurisdiction in certain matters. The point taken before the Sessions Judge was that by virtue of the said Act, the present case should have been tried by the Panchayati Adalat and that the Railway Magistrate had numberjurisdiction. This companytention was accepted by the learned Sessions Judge. He accordingly made a reference to the High Court for quashing the companyviction

facts.text: High Court Single Judge declined to accept reference on ground of discretionary revisional jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: It came before a Single Judge of the High Court who did number feel quite satisfied that the Railway Magistrate had jurisdiction. But without deciding the question one way or the other, he declined to accept the reference on the ground that the revisional jurisdiction of the High. Court was J. discretionary.

facts.text: High Court Judge granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Somewhat -curiously however, the learned Judge granted a certificate against his own judgment that the case is a fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Theft of property value Rs. 3.

anchor.surface_text: The charge-sheet filed by the police shows that the theft of the property involved in the case is Rs. 3.

facts.text: Offence committed within limits of Manikpur.

anchor.surface_text: There can also be numberdoubt that the offence has been companymitted within the limits of Manikpur.

facts.text: One of the three accused, Tulsi, belongs to Jubbalpore in Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: But in the present case it is on the record that one-out of the three accused by name Tulsi belongs to Jubbalpore in Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Railway Magistrate had jurisdiction to try the case.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the Railway Magistrate had the jurisdiction to try the case.

facts.text: U.P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947 applicable as stood at time of offence and conviction.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Act, as it stood at the time of the companymission of the offence- and the companyviction there for, the scheme thereunder is as follows

facts.text: Amendments to Act in 1952 and 1955 have no application to present case.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the Act appears to have undergone some amendments in the year 1952 and recently in 1955. These amendments have numberapplication to the present case.

facts.text: Appellant contended Railway Magistrate had no jurisdiction due to U.P. Panchayat Raj Act.

anchor.surface_text: The point taken before the Sessions Judge was that by virtue of the said Act, the present case should have been tried by the Panchayati Adalat and that the Railway Magistrate had numberjurisdiction.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held Railway Magistrate had no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention was accepted by the learned Sessions Judge.

facts.text: High Court Judge not satisfied Railway Magistrate had jurisdiction but did not decide.

anchor.surface_text: It came before a Single Judge of the High Court who did number feel quite satisfied that the Railway Magistrate had jurisdiction. But without deciding the question one way or the other,

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 15, 1955 by JAGANNADHADAS J.

anchor.surface_text: 1955. March 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J.-This is an appeal by leave granted by the High Court of Allahabad

facts.text: Panchayati Adalat could not constitute competent bench due to one accused from outside state.

issues.text: whether by virtue of the U.P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947, the present case should have been tried by the Panchayati Adalat and that the Railway Magistrate had no jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Against this conviction the present appellant filed a revision to the Sessions Judge of Banda. It is necessary at this stage to mention that under the U. P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947, the Panchayati Adalats in U. P. have criminal jurisdiction in certain matters. The point taken before the Sessions Judge was that by virtue of the said Act, the present case should have been tried by the Panchayati Adalat and that the Railway Magistrate had no jurisdiction.

issues.text: the question of jurisdiction thus raised

anchor.surface_text: the question involved so that we should have had the benefit of his consideration of the same. To decide the question of jurisdiction thus raised it is necessary to notice the scheme of the U. P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947  U.P. Act XXVI of 1947   here in after referred to as the Act  and a few relevant sections of the same.

issues.text: whether rule 84 in so far as it relates to the constitution of a special bench where one of the parties belongs to a place outside the State is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that rule 84 in so far as it relates to the constitution of a special bench where one of the parties belongs to a place outside the State is ultra vires. Hence no competent bench could be constituted under section 49 of the Act for the trial of the present case in which there are three accused of whom one is a person belonging to a different State.

issues.text: in these circumstances, it has to be considered whether the trial of this case by the ordinary criminal Court is barred
whether there is a valid machinery for the trial by Panchayati Adalat such that the jurisdiction of the regular Magistrate is barred under section 55

arguments.claim: By virtue of the U. P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947, the present case should have been tried by the Panchayati Adalat and that the Railway Magistrate had no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The point taken before the Sessions Judge was that by virtue of the said Act, the present case should have been tried by the Panchayati Adalat and that the Railway Magistrate had no jurisdiction. This contention was accepted by the learned Sessions Judge.

arguments.claim: Railway Magistrate had no jurisdiction to try the case; conviction should be quashed.

anchor.surface_text: This contention was accepted by the learned Sessions Judge. He accordingly made a reference to the High Court for quashing the conviction and sentence.

arguments.claim: Rule 84 insofar as it relates to constitution of special bench where one party belongs to place outside the State is ultra vires section 49(3).

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that rule 84 in so far as it relates to the constitution of a special bench where one of the parties belongs to a place outside the State is ultra vires.

arguments.claim: No competent bench could be constituted under section 49 for trial of present case due to one accused from different State.

anchor.surface_text: Hence no competent bench could be constituted under section 49 of the Act for the trial of the present case in which there are three accused of whom one is a person belonging to a different State.

arguments.claim: Trial by ordinary criminal court not barred by section 55 as bar applies only to cases with valid Panchayati Adalat machinery.
Section 55 bar relates to case as a whole requiring valid machinery; undefined here due to outsider accused.
Criminal courts' jurisdiction under CrPC section 5 is comprehensive; not excluded unless limited jurisdiction clearly operative.
Railway Magistrate had jurisdiction to try the case.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the Railway Magistrate had the jurisdiction to try the case.

holdings.text: We are clearly of the opinion that rule 84 in so far as it relates to the constitution of a special bench where one of the parties belongs to a place outside the State is ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that rule 84 in so far as it relates to the constitution of a special bench where one of the parties belongs to a place outside the State is ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 49(4) authorizes rules for special benches only for disputes between parties or Gaon Sabhas of different circles constituted under the Act; does not extend to parties from outside the State; 'for any other purpose' cannot be construed to include outsiders.

holdings.text: Hence no competent bench could be constituted under section 49 of the Act for the trial of the present case in which there are three accused of whom one is a person belonging to a different State.

anchor.surface_text: Hence no competent bench could be constituted under section 49 of the Act for the trial of the present case in which there are three accused of whom one is a person belonging to a different State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Due to one accused from outside the State and rule 84 being ultra vires, no valid bench under s49(1),(2) or special bench possible.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction of the regular criminal court in respect of such a case cannot be taken away by the operation of section 55 of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S55 bars cognizance of a 'case' (defined under s2(a) as proceeding triable by Panchayati Adalat including bench) as a whole; bar operative only if valid machinery exists; here no valid bench for all accused together.

holdings.text: It is to be remembered that the jurisdiction of the criminal courts under section 5 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is comprehensive... Exclusion of jurisdiction of a court of general jurisdiction... only if the vesting and the exercise of that limited jurisdiction is clear and operative.
holdings.reasoning_summary: CrPC s5 provides general jurisdiction; limited jurisdiction under Panchayat Act excludes it only where machinery is clear, vested, and operative; here not, due to bench issue.

holdings.text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the Railway Magistrate had the jurisdiction to try the case.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the Railway Magistrate had the jurisdiction to try the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Panchayati Adalat jurisdiction under ss52,55 not exercisable due to incompetent bench (ultra vires rule 84, no s49 bench); CrPC s5 jurisdiction remains for ordinary court including Railway Magistrate.
